item.title: What Stock Indexes Teach Us
item.description: A study, The Capitalism Distribution by Eric Crittenden and Cole Wilcox, analyzed the performance of approximately 8,000 U.S. stocks between 1983 and 2006. Surprisingly, while the S&P 500 Total Return Index increased by +1796% during this period, the average annualized return of all stocks was -1.06%. How can a market index do well when the average return of all stocks is negative? This post explores the studyâ€™s implications and introduces momentum trading.
